docs.lead_paragraph: Having spent more than $30 million to help elect their allies to Congress, the major drug companies are devising ways to capitalize on their electoral success by securing favorable new legislation and countering the pressure that lawmakers in both parties feel to lower the cost of prescription drugs, industry officials say. The industry's hand appears stronger now than at any other time in recent years, a result of its large donations to political parties and candidates and millions of dollars spent on television advertising by industry-financed groups. The money was spent overwhelmingly on behalf of Republicans, who now control both houses of Congress.

headline.main: Results of Elections Give Pharmaceutical Industry New Influence in Congress

docs.abstract: Pharmaceutical industry, which spent more than $30 million to help elect allies to Congress, is devising ways to secure favorable new legislation and counter pressure on lawmakers to lower drug costs; industry's hand appears stronger than at any time in recent years, given that money was spent overwhelmingly for Republicans, who now control both houses of Congress; drug executives mapping strategy with lobbyists are encouraged by amendment to domestic security bill that wouuld limit legal liability of manufacturers like Eli Lilly; key goal is shaping any Medicare drug program; Repr Rob Portman comments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Having spent more than $30 million to help elect their allies to Congress, the major drug companies are devising ways to capitalize on their electoral success by securing favorable new legislation and countering the pressure that lawmakers in both...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr

docs.lead_paragraph: The collapse of National Century Financial Enterprises toppled another of its clients yesterday when Doctors Community Healthcare -- a company based in Scottsdale, Ariz., that owns five hospitals in low-income neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.; Chicago and Southern California -- filed for Chapter 11 in the Federal Bankruptcy Court for the District of Columbia. Doctors Community joins several other major customers of National Century that have filed for bankruptcy since the health care finance company, based in Dublin, Ohio, began to come apart in late October. The PhyAmerica Physician Group in Durham, N.C.; Tender Loving Care, a unit of Med Diversified in Andover, Mass.; LifeCare Solutions in San Diego; and Lincoln Hospital Medical Center in Los Angeles have all sought Chapter 11 protection in the last two weeks after they stopped receiving payments from National Century.

headline.main: Fallout Spreads After Collapse Of a Health Services Lender

docs.abstract: Collapse of National Century Financial Enterprises topples another of its clients when Doctors Community Healthcare, which owns five hospitals in low-income neighborhoods in Washington, DC, Chicago and Southern California, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; Doctors Community joins several other major customers of National Century that have filed for bankruptcy since health company began to come apart in late October; PhyAmerica Physician Group, Tender Loving Care, unit of Med Diversified, LifeCare Solutions and Lincoln Hospital Medical Center have all sought Chapter 11 protection in last two weeks after they stopped receiving payments from National Century; hundreds of other National Century clients are also scrambling to find alternative financing; American Hospital Association spokesman Rick Wade comments; National Century has become target of FBI investigation and allegations of gross mismanagement brought by its clients and holders of $3.35 billion worth of asset-backed securities; former chairman-chief executive Lance K Poulsen resigned both posts on Nov 8 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Victor D. Herbert, whose experiments on himself 40 years ago showed that a shortage of folic acid found in leafy vegetables and fruits caused a type of anemia, died on Nov. 19 in New York City. He was 75. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Marilynne.

headline.main: Dr. Victor D. Herbert, 75; Linked Folic Acid to Anemia

docs.abstract: Dr Victor D Herbert, who linked anemia to lack of folic acid from leafy vegetables and fruits, dies at age 75; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vivendi Universal Faces Formal S.E.C. Investigation Vivendi Universal said that an informal inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission had become a formal investigation. Vivendi declined to provide details but said that it would cooperate with the S.E.C. inquiry as well as one by the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. The investigations in the United States come atop similar inquiries in France, where officials are looking into the timeliness and accuracy with which Vivendi's former chief executive disclosed information to investors. The American investigations are also thought to be focusing on financial disclosures. [Page C6.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences said today that the United States health care system was in crisis and that the Bush administration should immediately test possible solutions, including universal insurance coverage and no-fault payment for medical malpractice, in a handful of states. Administration officials said the report would probably become a blueprint for pilot projects to be proposed by President Bush and Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, who requested the study.

headline.main: U.S. Urged to Test Solutions To a 'Crisis' in Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: They have already watched their 401(k) savings evaporate, stood by as offices were closed, seen countless jobs disappear. But now, tens of thousands of Lucent Technologies retirees sense that the pain is not over yet. As Lucent struggles to cut costs and meet its obligations, the next thing that they fear will be lost is retirement medical coverage, a valuable benefit that more than 100,000 retirees now receive from the company.

headline.main: Another Cloud on the Horizon for Lucent Retirees

docs.abstract: Lucent Technologies retirees fear they will lose retirement medical coverage, valuable benefit for more than 100,000 retirees receive from company; some retirees foresee that if Lucent is ultimately forced to file bankruptcy protection some of them could lose part of their pensions; retiree James Fitzgerald and wife Margaret comment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 U.S. Doubles Its Troops For War Practice in Kuwait The United States Army has quietly doubled the number of its troops in Kuwait and is practicing offensive operations against Iraq close to the border with Saddam Hussein's forces. Army combat engineers have been trained to blow paths through minefields, and conducted infantry assaults against mock strongholds. A1 Labor Party Chooses Leader The Israeli opposition Labor Party chose as its standard-bearer Amram Mitzna, a former general who favors immediately opening peace talks with the Palestinians and withdrawing troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip, early election results showed. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of Americans who received psychotherapy increased slightly from 1987 to 1997, according to a large national study, and rose significantly for two groups: older adults and the unemployed. But the average length of time patients spent in the consulting room dropped precipitously over the same period, the study found, and the percentage of patients who combined psychotherapy with psychiatric medication nearly doubled.

headline.main: Psychotherapy Shows a Rise Over Decade, But Time Falls

docs.abstract: New study finds number of Americans who received psychotherapy increased slightly from 1987 to 1997, rising significantly among older adults and unemployed; finds average length of time patients spent in therapy dropped precipitously in period and percentage of patients who combined therapy and psychiatric medication nearly doubled; researchers say findings reflect impact of managed care and growing popularity of brief forms of psychotherapy; Dr Mark Olfson, who led study, says therapy continues to play key role in American mental health care (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at New York University Hospitals Center say they have no idea how anti-union literature appeared at the homes of nearly 400 clerical workers days before they narrowly voted against allowing a powerful hospital union to represent them. The literature, which contained material that an arbitrator had barred management from issuing because it was misleading, bore no return address or hint of the sender's identity. It was distributed in envelopes, sealed with surgical tape.
docs.abstract: New York University Hospitals Center denies sending anti-union literature to homes of 400 clerical workers just before hospital workers voted to prohibit Local 1199/SEIU from representing hospital (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: These are gloomy times for those who plead for fiscal discipline in the federal government, and not simply because the budget has swung from surplus to deficit in the last year. Even the most passionate champions of a balanced budget see little danger in this year's deficit of $159 billion and similar shortfalls for the next two or three years.

headline.main: Who's Afraid of the Deficit? Cassandras Are Out of Style

docs.abstract: Analysis: Advocates pf balanced budget see little danger in this year's deficit of $159 million and similar shortfalls for next two or three yearss; say real problems are coming: soaring costs for Social Security, Medicare and other benefit programs as oldest baby boomers starting reaching retirement age around 2010; Congressional Budget Office has repeatedly warned that if nothing is changed, government will spend as much on Social Security, Medicaid and Medicare by 2030 as it does for its entire budget today; office projects current cycle of deficits will end by 2006; Concord Coalition, private organization, predicts deficits will deepen because Congress will not be able to live within those contraints; graph (M)
